reviews.review:
I am not even joking when I say that I have just played this game after buying it a couple years back and beaten it in 2.5 hours (excluding the post-game content). I wasn't sure if this was supposed to be longer and I'd rushed through it like a madman or maybe it's how the game's length is, but if so than wow. 

So many people had kept pushing me to get Portal and praised it to be one of the greatest games of all time; and to that I can see where they're coming from, but I don't feel it being one of the greatest games of all time fits it. Portal isn't bad by any means, it had me using my melted cheese brain and whenever I passed through an obstacle I've been having trouble with, I get a satisfying smile and pat myself on the back for what I accomplished. 

The problem is that there wasn't enough to be had in the main game (again, excluding the post game content) and enough to be taken in by the game's world/setting. Not even with the "secret areas" sold it to me as they were nothing more than just a simple: "Oop, here you go" and that's it. One occasion that I have to give props for is that Portal and Half-Life are connected if you peek through one of the conference rooms in the ending levels to see a slide show of Black Mesa and Aperture Science being in a slide show about profit or whatever. That I like a lot. 

I probably butchered and left out some other things as well, but that is all I could think of. Portal is a pretty alright game that everyone should experience once. It's challenging, rewarding, and heck GLaDOS kept things from being a total snooze fest thanks to her voice actress and writing. But as for me, I think it'll be a one and done kind of thing unless I'm feeling nostalgic.

The first 50% of the game was rather easy, nothing too special. But things really picked up in the 2nd half, with puzzles that fully test your understanding of the game’s physics, portal placement, movement and reaction speed. I enjoyed GlaDOS’s dark humor through the story. The final level is also pretty neat.

There’s also a free dev console to mess around with cheats in the game so that’s always nice lol
De lo mejor de Valve. Muy recomendado.
An absolute MUST-PLAY & an ALL-TIME CLASSIC. A wonderful puzzle game with mechanics & puzzles that have withstood the test of nearly two decades of time.
Are you reading the reviews? Play this game, the best puzzle game. Don't @ me

Buen juego recomendado, genial para pensar con sus puzzles, algunos niveles dificiles pero con fe se puede pasar :3, y un gran credito final.

Portal es una experiencia basada en puzzles, muy innovadora para su época y relativa mente corta, razón por lo cual considero que es apta para cualquier tipo de jugador que busque algo distinto. Los mapas avanzados y desafíos aumentan un poco la duración e incluso tiene coleccionables. Altamente recomendable.

8/10.
Pretty fun, but it's a short game. If you could only buy 1, you should buy Portal 2, but get the portal collection during sales.

without question, Portal is one of the greatest video games of all time. maybe it's a little dated by today's standards but i still come back and replay it all the time. the question isn't "should you play it" but rather "how have you not played it yet?"

Absolutely brilliant, now one of my favourite single player story games! DEFINITELY RECOMMEND, especially for only £7! While the levels and unique game designs are super, i love the story-line/background! Thanks valve!

Great mind twisting fun. The first time I played Portal I was trying to make the real word conform to Portal's unique physics.  This is a great puzzle game as puzzles are unique and are different than any puzzle game that you could have. Except for it's successor Portal 2, You will not find any game like it. I promise you, you have never played a game like this.  One of a kind. the graphics and game play are solid. Even though the Computer lies to you occasionally. Not a bug, but a lie to make that puzzle more fun.

Portal is a First Person Puzzle game released as part of The Orange Box.
The game takes place in the Half-Life universe, in the Portal Nature Research Laboratory, but has nothing to do with the plot of Half-Life Portal itself. The main character of the work is called Chell, who creates the portals themselves with the help of a manual portal device, through which she is able to move and move objects.

The whole game consists of 19 test rooms, the transitions between which are carried out using an elevator, as well as a number of utility rooms. As you progress through to solve increasingly difficult puzzles, the player will have to combine different techniques. For most of the game, Chell travels under the supervision of the supercomputer GLaDOS, however, towards the end of the game, Chell goes out of control and tries to escape from the Laboratory.

Think we all have nostalgia with this game but even years later it's great. I mean granted it only takes a couple hours to finish even if you haven't played in years but its solid story wise and had me stumped in a couple levels. solid game and the best out of them.

This game is a lot of fun and easy to see how modern games might be inspired from its physics engine. Starts simple enough but gets trickier and more challenging with each level. The final level is quite something!

How can you not love portal? its such a simple and straightforward game that you can play through it in just a few hours, but the story and dialogue brings joy to everyone. and who doesnt love what's probably the most emotional end credits since the lord of the rings? seriously, i sing my kid to sleep with that song. im sure that wont bite me on the ass later in life! 

Look, i know you're not even reading this. who the hell has ever been on the fence about buying portal? nobody! so why would the reviews get read in the first place? just spend the 2 bucks and see the game that literally changed the world.
